This will continue the long standing practice in Eire, whereby, on a basis of reciprocity, citizens of Commonwealth countries are exempted from treatment as aliens. (The point at this second sta^ is that the privilages will, subject of course to r reciprocity, be placed on a statutory basis and will not depend on an order made at discretion). 16th November16th November between Eire Ministers and Ministers representing the United Kingdom, Canada, Australia and New Zealand, the four Commonwealth countries in which there are the largest communities of Irish origin. The Governments of all the other Commonwealth countries and the Government of Northern Ireland were also consulted in advance of the Prime Minister's statement on 25th November. 2. As regards possibility that nations having treaties with United Kingdom containing most-favoured-nation clauses may claim the same treatment as the United Kingdom accords to Eire or the right to form similar relationships themselves with other foreign countries, position for your confidential information is that it was agreed with Eire ministers during Paris discussions that Eire Government would collaborate with United Kingdom Government and any other interested Commonwealth Governments in resisting any such claims. Grounds on which this resistance would be based have not yet been finally determined, but general line of argument would probably be:- (a) The United Kingdom and Eire stand in a relationship to one another which is quite unlike the i^lationship in which either stands to any foreign country. This special relationship consists in ties of kinship, geographical proximity, and long association. (b) In making present arrangements neither country is granting the other any new privileges but is merely maintaining the status quo. (c) Since His Majesty's Government in the United Kingdom have declared that they do not regard Eire as a 'foreign' country or her citizens as 'foreigners', any benefits or privileges which the United Kingdom may continue to grant to Eire or her citizens cannot legitimately be claimed by any country which is foreign to the United Kingdom. 3. This exchange of rights and privilage$, which it is our firm desire and intention to maintain and strength€ in our view constitutes a special relationship which negatives the view that other countries could raise valid objections on the grounus that Ireland should be treated as a 'foreign' country by Britain and the Commonwealth Countries, for the purpose of this exchange of rights and privilages'.INDIA OFFICE RECORDS ~

physicalDescription.extent: The file’s contents are arranged in approximate chronological order, from the earliest item at the front to the latest at the end. The office notes at the end of the file (folio 5) mirror the chronological arrangement.

mods.abstract: The file contains a single item of note, a telegram from the Foreign Office to His Majesty’s representatives at Bahrain, dated 14 December 1948, on the subject of Eire (the Republic of Ireland) and the Commonwealth. The telegram was sent in response to the ratification of the Republic of Ireland Act of 1948, which formally announced Ireland’s status as a republic, and the end of the constitutional rule of the British monarchy in the state. The telegram sets out the British Government’s position on the Act, prior to its coming into force in 1949.The telegram states:the expected relations that will exist between Great Britain and Ireland;that Britain will not regard Ireland as a ‘foreign country’ and its citizens not as foreigners;Ireland’s position in relation to the Commonwealth;how British officials might address the claims of other countries which have treaties with Britain containing ‘most-favoured-nation clauses’, and the arguments that Britain will use to resist such claims.
